name: transport, passenger car, small size, natural gas, EURO 3 | transport, passenger car, small size, natural gas, EURO 3 | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/2888/documentation

This dataset represents the service of transport in a passenger car for a journey length of 1vkm and is valid for Europe. Fuel consumption and emissions are for average vehicle use and not representative of a specific driving cycle. The dataset is parametrized with respect to vehicle size, fuel consumption and vehicle lifetime. ;Datasets for three different passenger car categories are available in ecoinvent in view of size: small, medium and large.;The category “small” includes passenger cars with engine size up to 1.4 liters. The average weight of this category is estimated to be 1200 kg. ;The category “medium” includes passenger cars with engine size between 1.4 and 2.0 liters. The average weight of this category is estimated to be 1600 kg. ;The category “large” includes passenger cars with engine size larger than 2.0 liters. The average weight of this category is estimated to be 2000 kg. ;The passenger car size influences the amount of both exhaust and non-exhaust emissions. The exhaust emissions caused by the burning of fuel are divided into two groups: fuel dependent emissions (dependent on fuel type and quantity) and Euro class dependent emissions which reflect the emission standards which the vehicle complies with. Three classes of Euro engine type are considered: Euro 3, Euro 4 and Euro 5.  The higher the class (e.g. Euro 5), the lower the emissions and viceversa. The Euro engine regulation is set by the European Commission “in order to limit as much as possible the negative impact of road vehicles on the environment and health” (European Commission 2012). This dataset considers a small petrol passenger car of Euro 5 class. Also included within the direct exchanges to the environment are the fuel evaporation emissions from the fuel tank, relevant to petrol vehicles only. ;;Non-exhaust emissions are those resulting from tyre, brake and road wear. These emissions are considered as by-products. ;;Reference: European Commission - Mobility and transport. (n.d.). Euro 5 and Euro 6 standards: reduction of pollutant emissions from light. Retrieved May 31, 2012, from http://ec.europa.eu/transport/index_en.htm: http://ec.europa.eu/transport/urban/vehicles/doc/legislation_guide_other.pdf

The construction of the datasets allows changing key parameters (vehicle size, fuel type and fuel consumption). However, it is important to consider that changing one parameter of a vehicle, e.g. its mass, may lead to changes in other parameters, e.g. the consumption. When modifying the default parameters given, attention should be paid to the possible influence which one parameter may have over the other.  

The activity ends with the transport over 1vkm and the emissions of exhaust and non-exhaust emissions into air, water and soil. 

The dataset includes the construction, operation, maintenance and disposal of the vehicle and road infrastructure. Operation of the vehicle includes all the direct emissions produced by fuel combustion and evaporation as well as from tyre, brake and road wear. 

The dataset doesn't specifically model cold start emissions. These are assumed to be included in the data for average driving which was used.
category: H:Transportation and storage/49:Land transport and transport via pipelines/492:Other land transport/4922:Other passenger land transport

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Transport in a passenger car with internal combustion engine fueled by natural gas. The passenger car size is small, with engine size up to 1.4 litres and average weight of 1200 kg. ;Technology classifications are based on those used widely within the works of the European Environment Agency, particularly in the Emissions Inventory Guidebook. The Tremove model - which is also used to generate fuel consumption and emission factors for the datasets presented here - follows this classification system.

exchanges.description: Emissions dependent on engine Euro class (Euro 3, Euro 4 and Euro 5).

flow.name: Particulate Matter, < 2.5 um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Calculations are based on data from Alvarez & Weilenmann (2010) Tracing of Road Traffic Emissions: Natural Gas Vehicles Euro-4 & Euro-5 Program. EMPA, Dübendorf.

Fuel consumption is influenced by vehicle weight. Fuel input exchanges (petrol low-sulphur, diesel low-sulphur and natural gas) are scaled on the specific vehicle weight inserted by the ecoinvent user. The scaling factor is estimated to be 2.93E-05.

The scaling factor corresponds to the difference in terms of fuel consumption of the two extremes that compose each class of passenger car emerging from the match between the three sizes and the three Euro categories. The result is then divided by the difference of the two extremes weight of each emerged class, which is 300 kg for all size categories.

The size 'large' has extremes of 2000 kg and 2300 kg. The scaling factor of a large passenger cars natural gas Euro 3 is therefore calculated as:
((specific vehicle weight - weight of minor extreme) * 2.93E-05 + fuel consumption of minor extreme).

This corresponds to:
((specific vehicle weight - 2000 kg) * 2.93E-05 + 7.26E-02

exchanges.description:
This input indicates the unit of road per vkm used during the transport activity.

The road input is composed by two demand factors:
- Road infrastructure and disposal (RI&D), which varies according to the gross vehicle weight. 

- Road operations & maintenance (RO&M), which does not vary according to the gross vehicle weight.

exchanges.description: The dataset is for a medium size passenger car. In order to make the demand appropriate to the particular vehicle in question a scaling factor is applied which is the product of the vehicle weight devided by the weight of the medium size vehicle.

exchanges.description: Quantity of emissions based on values from Ntziachristos, L., Boulter, P. (2009) EMEP/EEA air pollutant emissions inventory guidebook 2009: Road vehicle tyre and brake wear; Road surface wear. Copenhagen, European Environment Agency. Quantities given in the source assumed to represent medium sized vehicles. Quantities for small and large vehicles taken from the bounds of the ranges given.
